title: Nanocosmos Shows Nature’s Invisible Art
intro: Artist Michael Benson reveals the hidden beauty of snowflakes, radiolarians and lunar rocks through stunning electron microscope images in his new book, Nanocosmos.

transcript.text: This episode was made possible by the support of Yakult and produced independently by Scientific American’s board of editors.

transcript.author: Michael Benson
transcript.text: So the snowflakes were a different story altogether. [Flips to a page in his book Nanocosmos.] So there’s the classic one.
You know, I lived in Ottawa, Ontario, for six years.

transcript.author: Kendra Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Three years of continuous snowflake production [Laughs] because it’s—because really it, the winter, lasts for half the year.

I worked out a methodology to get snowflakes into the vacuum chamber of the electron microscope using liquid nitrogen. I had this kind of cryopod, which was used to take DNA samples around Canada. So you can capture the flakes and keep them at -200 or something degrees, something incredibly cold … and then you have a shot at getting it into the vacuum chamber.
Ice in general doesn’t like a vacuum, and it doesn’t like being hit by electron beams.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: You know, it, it sublimates, and it melts. But you have about three minutes to capture a snowflake. And so we worked out a methodology to get high-quality SEM [scanning electron microscope] images of, of snowflakes. [Flips to another page of the book.] That’s a close view of the center of this thing. You can see why no two snowflakes are, are alike when you look with a microscope like this because they’re so complex, you know? [Points to an image in Nanocosmos.] This one has a bisected tine.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And when I first saw it I thought, “Oh, it’s too bad it’s not perfect. I can’t really use this one.” And then a minute later I said, “Wait a second, this is how it looks. Use this,” you know? And actually, I think it’s beautiful.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: It is beautiful.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Mm.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: For Scientific American’s Science Quickly, I’m Kendra Pierre-Louis, in for Rachel Feltman.
Radiolarians are single-celled organisms that live in water and are [typically] invisible to the naked eye. But under microscope these creatures take on an almost glassinelike quality.

Their beauty, along with that of other tiny creatures, and some extreme close-up images of lunar rocks are the subject of Michael Benson’s recently released book, Nanocosmos: Journeys in Electron Space. In it he uses a specific type of microscope, a scanning electron microscope, often used by scientists for research, to create beautiful art that he hopes will help instill a sense of wonder and awe in the world.

And just a note to all of you listeners, Michael and I were together to look through his stunning new book, and we made a video version of this podcast so that you can look, too. Head over to our YouTube to see snowflakes, radiolarians and moon rocks in all of their visual glory.
We have Michael Benson here with us today. Thank you so much for coming.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Thank you very much for inviting me. I’m, I’m really looking forward to talking about my project.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Your earlier books, you know, Planetfall and Cosmigraphics, really focused on sort of the beauty and the enormity of space, and this is a little bit the opposite. Like, you spent seven years in a tiny room in Canada ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Looking at tiny things. Why did you decide to switch it up?

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: A lot of people don’t even remember the name Buckminster Fuller.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: He was a prominent futurist, very famous in the mid-20th century. And he was being interviewed, apparently, by a young journalist, a little bit nervous talking to the great man towards the end of his life, and the journalist said, “You’ve spent a career prognosticating about colonies in space and our position in space. Does it ever bother you that you haven’t actually been to space?” And Fuller looked at him and said. “My God, man, where do you think we are?”

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And my point is that, actually, this is not that different from the other work I’ve been doing; it’s just that it’s at a different scale. It’s all about space and time, looking at how we try to understand our position and space and time using images, but I also write.

And with the electron microscope work it was finally having a chance to look at phenomena here on this planet. I wanted to look at natural design at submillimeter scales, so smaller than a grain of salt.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: So huge, basically [Laughs].

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: So huge, basically—well, okay ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: I’m kidding [Laughs].

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Well, no, it’s huge if you’re talking about, you know, atomic physics or something—we’re talking about large structures. That’s true [Laughs]. And we are talking about atomic physics because the electron microscope uses the electron and not the photon to look at subjects.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah, I was gonna ask you about that. What makes a scanning electron microscope so different from [a] conventional lens-based microscope?

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: It’s quite different. It’s—first of all it takes up most of a room. It uses electrons instead of photons to look at the subjects, which allows for a far more detailed, nuanced, accurate look at extremely high magnifications of subjects.
From a very young age I was aware of electron micro—microscopy images, invariably presented as belonging to scientific research. But I’m an artist and a writer, and I’m not a, I’m not a scientist ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Although I am very science-adjacent. I use scientific technologies to explore phenomenal reality for my purposes.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: You know, which is, you know, more associated with the arts; it is not science.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: In what way is it art? Because I think when people think about taking an image of something or preparing a slide—what are the choices you’re making that make it different from, say, what people think of when they think of science?

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: So scientific imaging is about research and empirical data acquisition. I am positioning my work as belonging to the history of, of the image.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: The, the history of photography—although, in this case, it’s [micrography].

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: But it looks like photography, and it’s printed like photography. And in fact, I approach it like photography, even—although it’s using a million-dollar piece of scientific research equipment that never leaves a single room—you know, a room ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: You can’t take it around [Laughs] and take photos with it. You have to bring the subjects to it.
There is a real learning curve learning how to use that kind of instrument ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And I have been fortunate in having the confidence of the Canadian Museum of Nature in Gatineau, Québec.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: I had a training period, and then they let me loose on the instrument.
It’s a very complex set of procedures just to get a sample ready for the SEM.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: SEM: scanning electron microscope.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And that’s all exactly the same as what any scientist would do, exactly the same, you know?

Art has a freer hand than science. Art does not have to justify itself and prove things. Art is about sublimity—it can be—and about evoking wonder and about triggering aesthetic and emotional responses. And art is also, to quote something Brian Eno said recently—I don’t think he invented this, but it’s an interesting point—that art is, in some ways, how adults play.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And furthermore, play is not wasting time—play, in children, is about figuring out their place in the universe in a way, to simplify.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And in my case this work is, in part, an extension of that impulse. You know, how to continue producing in myself this sense of wonder about our place in the universe, about the universe, you know, the phenomenal reality. And I’m also fascinated by frontiers.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: One of the sets of images that open up the book are of these lunar moon rocks, and it’s interesting looking at them because they do—they look like mountainscapes to me.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: What are we looking at? [Gestures at a page in Nanocosmos.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: So it’s lunar impact glass, and it was a piece of ejecta, as they call it, you know, from a macrometeorite impact millions of years ago the Apollo 16 astronauts just kind of casually noticed lying on the lunar surface when they were doing something else and raked up—they had these rakes, sample rakes—and just threw in their sample bag and brought back to Earth.
Every single lunar image in the book—there aren’t that many ... [Flips to another page.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: This is another lunar mountain range. They all came from the same piece of impact glass, which I just found marvelously ravaged and geological and, and, you know, landscapelike.
This is all fracturing ... [Points to an image in the book.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: From, from the impact, and—and I guess from the impact of the glass when it hit the surface. And then, and then, you know, there was—there were millions of years of exposure to space that resulted in various forms of weathering, let’s say.
[Flips to another page.] Here you have micrometeorite impacts.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Oh, yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: So they have—you can see, you know, characteristic lines radiating out, just like in macro lunar craters that we can see with a—through a telescope.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah, that’s really cool.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yeah. I very consciously wanted to make landscapes, lunar landscapes, on Earth. They look like Utah or Arizona slick rock country, you know? [Laughs.] They look very geological, and they are geological. It looks like something you could climb, you know? [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah, it does.
Can I ask a very silly question?

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Absolutely.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Did you lick it?

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: No.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Lick it—why?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: I don’t know. There’s, like, a whole trend where—or a thing where people, like, feel compelled to, like, lick rocks, and you got [Laughs] ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Oh, my God, these are Apollo samples. No chance would I, you know—and, and, and in fact, I wasn’t allowed to coat them. Because most samples you put in the electron microscope are coated with a molecule-thin layer of [a conductive material such as] platinum so that they don’t charge.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And that’s complicated to explain. But you have an electron beam hitting the subject, you know, and if it’s not grounded with, with that coating, it can charge, and, and so on. And so I had issues with—I, of course, I couldn’t do that; these are priceless samples.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And so I couldn’t do that, so I had to figure out ways of imaging, imaging them without them—their charging, and nobody who listens to this podcast is gonna sit through an explanation of how I did that ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: But, but I did manage to do that. But no, I did not lick them. [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Laughs.] I mean ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: It’s a good question, though. [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Many of the images, like the image of the weevil in a flowering plant—I really like that one ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Become almost a world unto themselves ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Because they’re taken so closely. They’re obviously so beautiful, but is there also, like, a scientific benefit to taking pictures like these?

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Whether or not there’s a scientific benefit is beyond me, but as I said earlier I am fascinated by frontiers, wherever they may be. I define a frontier as where, where what we know or think we know meets what we know we don’t know ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: You know? And, and, and there’s this sort of hazy zone in the sciences, where, where all of this research is taking place, and I am fascinated by that, but I’m not a scientist ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: I go there as an artist, looking for my kind of “discovery.”
You know, with those images of insects in plants, you know, I, I did have the benefit of being able to speak to and actually get loans from entomologists ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: At the Museum of Nature. So I was asking things like, “Well, what does that thing do?” And then I would typically get an answer [such as], “Well, we believe it’s for this,” and I realize I’m at the frontier, you know?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: “We believe it may be for this,” you know? So that’s, you know, that’s an interesting place.
[Gestures to a page in Nanocosmos.] So this is a flowering plant from the Adriatic, and when I collected it—the Croatian side of the Adriatic Sea ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And when I collected it—I mean, this is incredibly small. It’s about—the, the entire plant, let’s check [Flips to another page], the entire plant is eight millimeters wide, so that’s, you know, under a centimeter wide. And when I collected this thing with tweezers and put it in ethanol, I noticed that there was this weevil in it.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And then they both, they both went in the ethanol. And so what you’re seeing is this kind of—I mean, very, very close to how it would look in actual nature, you know?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: If someone actually paid attention to look.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Because—I mean, because it’s so small, it just feels like a thing that most of us would overlook.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Oh, yeah, of course. I mean, and also, who really looks at all those really tiny flowers? You just kind of trundle along, you know? [Laughs.] But I—one of the reasons why I really had a lot of fun with this project is it changed my way of looking at—my way of being in nature, you know?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: I mean, I was—of course, it was a little bit predatory [Laughs] when I was collecting samples.

[Flips through pages of Nanocosmos.] And there’s another one that’s similar to this that is even more ambitious in a way. In fact, I think it’s the single most complex mosaic I did in the whole book—all of these are mosaic images, by the way; they’re comprised of hundreds of individual scans. [Points to an image.] This is the one.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Oh.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yeah, so that is—that’s from a—that’s an Ontario plant and a foxglove aphid in it.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Oh, yeah. [Points to a part of the image.] Right there.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Right there, yeah. And that one took about three weeks of continuous work to assemble because the, the individual SEM frame was something like this. [Turns the page to a closer view and indicates the size of the frame with his hands.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: You know? And then there’s also a depth-of-field question. So, I mean, not to get all nuts and bolts on you here, but, you know, sometimes I had to do focus-stacking, get multiple scans of one part of the, of the subject in order to stack them in Photoshop and make sure everything was in focus, and then, you know, build a complex mosaic. So, yeah.
And this is—this has some elements of—you know that famous painting with the tiger in the jungle [Laughs] ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Oh, yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: There’s a little bit of that going on.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Art isn’t prescriptive, but, like, what do you hope that people get from seeing these images?

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: I don’t know. I mean, you know, for example, those—the weevil surrounded by flowering plants was consciously modeled after 16th- and 17th-century Dutch still-life painting, where you’d see all the—you could see all these flowers and insects, all in a perfect arrangement, and just kind of, you know, life in miniature.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: It’s about triggering an aesthetic response. It’s about showing worlds that you can’t see with the naked eye, but we have these tools now to see them.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: See these worlds, you know? That, that also is all bound to this question of the frontier, of course.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.
Radiolarians, there’re these, like, you know, microscopic, basically, organisms ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: They are microscopic.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: That live in the ocean.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yep.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: And—but they’re so beautiful. They’re almost, like, glassine in structure ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: They are.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: But we would never be able to know about them without, you know, advancements in imaging, functionally.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Well, it’s interesting—radiolarians are specifically a, a, a central focus of the 19th-century German marine biologist Ernst Haeckel. He’s best known to the layperson as the author of a book that, in English, the title is Art Forms in Nature, which is really the first arts-science crossover illustrated book bestseller ever. And it’s still in print.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: It’s incredible, you know? So he brought, let’s say, the message about radiolarians to the public in the late 19th century ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Discovered many of them. His work impacted design and architecture and art. He was using an optical microscope—the, the electron microscope had not been invented yet.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: He would’ve been envious, I think. [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: I could look at radiolarians with a level of particularity that he could only dream of. But he did produce extraordinary work about radiolarians and many other organisms: diatoms, dinoflagellates … all kinds of things.

[Flips to a page in Nanocosmos.] So this is a radiolarian from the equatorial Pacific. It’s, it’s 300 microns wide, which means 0.3 millimeters; it’s extremely small. But look at the complexity there. And, you know, when it was fully intact and not partly damaged, it had a whole shell of this kind of latticework going on there [gestures to an image in the book]. And, you know, there—I write in the book about what all of these things are, we think, are doing, or at least to an extent: you know, what the—those radiating spines are all about. It’s partly about flotation in the water column. Yeah, so.
But the, the beauty of it is breathtaking to me. [Flips the page.] Here’s a closer ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Closer.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: View.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yeah. I mean, it’s—there’s nothing like radiolarians anywhere else in nature that I’ve seen. I mean, in, in, in ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Biological nature that I’ve seen. They’re, they’re quite specific.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: And I think if we pop over here [Turns to another page] ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Mm-hmm. Yeah, so these are, these are diatoms.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And diatoms are another class of single-celled organism, and, and they tend to be much more sleek, as you can see here. And interestingly about diatoms, diatoms produce oxygen in the Earth’s atmosphere…

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: But they’re tiny, little things, you know? It’s just that there are billions of them. You have, you know, you have diatom blooms ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: You see these long tendrils—you can see it from space, you know—of kind of greenish blooms in the water.

And all of the, the shells are actually glass—I mean, they’re silica, just like with radiolarians, by the way. The radiolarians are also—they distill silica from seawater and produce their, their shells from that. And under an optical microscope they look like glass.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: In an SEM you see the surface texture of the, of the glass, you know?

But the reason they do that—I mean, the reason that they have to be clear—is that they’re like petri dishes. [Laughs.] They have, they have symbiotic photosynthesis going on: algae living inside, producing energy.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Oh, that’s ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: For them, yeah.
[Looking at another page.] That’s, that’s a marine, marine diatom. Like a pillbox, isn’t it?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yeah. I mean, these—this just blows, blows me away. I mean, there, there’s an element of Islamic architecture, somehow, in here. [Turns the page.] This is a close view. I mean, this could be something in Istanbul, you know?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Flip it upside—flip it the other way, and it, and it could be the top of a building, you know, connected to a mosque or something.

[Flips back to the previous page.] Yeah, and so, you know, again, you know, what you have here, this is almost literally a petri dish. Look at it—it’s the same shape [laughs]. It’s a little bit more beautiful ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Points to part of the image on the page]—yeah, it’s almost, like, got lacing in there.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yep, yep.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: [Flips to another page.] And then we’re gonna bounce forward again.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yep, so that’s a dinoflagellate, and, and we were talking about them earlier. I mean, they are so strange. They are so beautiful to me.

You have—usually, you have this sort of equatorial groove [Points to part of the image on the page] where one of the flagella coils around. And then you’ve got the—this, you know, polar opening here, where another flagella extends. They spin for stability, like a spacecraft might. [Laughs.] And then they’re propelled at the other end by this—another flagella, which shoots them forward. And they’re just amazing things, you know. And we don’t know what, what this is all about. What are these guys up to?
You know, there—I think that there’s a tendency to think that, “Well, we’re multicellular creatures, so a single cell must be a very simple thing.”

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: You know, “’Cause we are complex, and we are made of many cells.” Well, it’s not so simple. I mean, the single-celled organisms that have managed to survive and compete with each other and prosper in the sea are—have just as much evolutionary history as we do. I mean, you know, four point something billion years, right?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Or three point something, yeah. I really should know that, but we don’t, we don’t know that—nobody knows that for sure. In any case ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: It’s been a while. [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: [Laughs.] It’s been a long time. It’s been a long, it’s been a long time.
So they—they’re very complex, and, you know, their survival strategies, their structural complexity is a result of the necessity to prosper, to go forth and prosper, you know?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: They had the same marching orders as Adam and Eve, I think, you know: “Go forth and prosper.” That’s, that’s life’s principle. [Laughs.] And, and so, you know, they’re, they’re very complex. They—and also, I guess nobody who actually knows anything about cells would say, “Well, a single cell is a, is a simple thing.” It’s—we—it’s a mysterious, complex, magical, amazing thing, anyway, even in a multicellular organism like us.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: But, but the ones that are free-floating and competing with each other are particularly amazing.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: It feels like, in this moment, it’s really easy to be very cynical about everything, that there’s a lot of weight and heft going on in the world ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yeah, there is.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: But hearing you talk about this book and this project, it seems like it reinforced your sense of wonder and ...

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Joy.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yes, yes.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: And I know that, you know, people have many emotions in looking at art, but it does feel like that if you—if people take away anything from your work, it should be kind of a sense of just how beautiful and weird and strange this world is.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Yes, thank you. That’s a great question. And you’re right. There’s also a spiritual element here. You know, I’m not a believer in any kind of organized religion, but, but I’m awestruck by where we are, you know, and, and, and, and, and so there is a, you know, there’s an element of, you know—I mean, okay, it sounds like a real cliche here—but communing or trying to understand, you know, “What is this? What is this project called life?” You know?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And you’re right, you know, it—we are living in times where, with a lot of help from algorithms and social media and certain toxic politicians and so forth, we are focusing on negative things, largely, and our—on ourselves. The human race, like any life-form, probably, is focused on its own self, you know, largely. But my work has been to, in, in a sense, turn my back on—at least the visual work—on, on the, on the human race ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And look at nature, look at nonhuman phenomena.
Now, I don’t do that as a writer. I’m fascinated by the history of, of technology and science, and I have an opening essay in the book where I, where I trace the history of the microscope ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: So I’m, you know, I’m part of the human race, obviously. [Laughs.] I’m not an alien. But, but I do ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Or at least that’s what you want us to believe. [Laughs.]

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Well, maybe we’re all, maybe we’re all aliens; that’s another question. But in any, in any case it is about drawing the human gaze, ideally, away from our political squabbles, our social media, our—I don’t know, you know, all of these things that are pretty banal, actually, when you look at it, or I would say so. And look at—look out, look at where we are, look at the larger environment that actually produced us ...

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Mm-hmm.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: And look at creatures and organisms and phenomena that, that have developed alongside us for the same length of time as we have, you know?

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Yeah. That feels like a good place to end this conversation. Thank you so much for your time. Thank you for joining us today.

transcript.author: Benson
transcript.text: Thank you very much for allowing me to expound on [Laughs], on my work. I appreciate it very much.

transcript.author: Pierre-Louis
transcript.text: Science Quickly is produced by me, Kendra Pierre-Louis, along with Fonda Mwangi and Jeff DelViscio–who also edited this episode. Shayna Posses and Aaron Shattuck fact-check our show. Our theme music was composed by Dominic Smith. Subscribe to Scientific American for more up-to-date and in-depth science news. And don’t forget to tune in next week when we take a deep dive into all things wild turkey.

lines: This episode was made possible by the support of Yakult and produced independently by Scientific American’s board of editors.
So the snowflakes were a different story altogether. [Flips to a page in his book Nanocosmos.] So there’s the classic one.
You know, I lived in Ottawa, Ontario, for six years.
Mm-hmm.
Three years of continuous snowflake production [Laughs] because it’s—because really it, the winter, lasts for half the year.

I worked out a methodology to get snowflakes into the vacuum chamber of the electron microscope using liquid nitrogen. I had this kind of cryopod, which was used to take DNA samples around Canada. So you can capture the flakes and keep them at -200 or something degrees, something incredibly cold … and then you have a shot at getting it into the vacuum chamber.
Ice in general doesn’t like a vacuum, and it doesn’t like being hit by electron beams.
[Laughs.]

You know, it, it sublimates, and it melts. But you have about three minutes to capture a snowflake. And so we worked out a methodology to get high-quality SEM [scanning electron microscope] images of, of snowflakes. [Flips to another page of the book.] That’s a close view of the center of this thing. You can see why no two snowflakes are, are alike when you look with a microscope like this because they’re so complex, you know? [Points to an image in Nanocosmos.] This one has a bisected tine.
Mm-hmm.

And when I first saw it I thought, “Oh, it’s too bad it’s not perfect. I can’t really use this one.” And then a minute later I said, “Wait a second, this is how it looks. Use this,” you know? And actually, I think it’s beautiful.
It is beautiful.
Mm.
For Scientific American’s Science Quickly, I’m Kendra Pierre-Louis, in for Rachel Feltman.
Radiolarians are single-celled organisms that live in water and are [typically] invisible to the naked eye. But under microscope these creatures take on an almost glassinelike quality.

Their beauty, along with that of other tiny creatures, and some extreme close-up images of lunar rocks are the subject of Michael Benson’s recently released book, Nanocosmos: Journeys in Electron Space. In it he uses a specific type of microscope, a scanning electron microscope, often used by scientists for research, to create beautiful art that he hopes will help instill a sense of wonder and awe in the world.

And just a note to all of you listeners, Michael and I were together to look through his stunning new book, and we made a video version of this podcast so that you can look, too. Head over to our YouTube to see snowflakes, radiolarians and moon rocks in all of their visual glory.
We have Michael Benson here with us today. Thank you so much for coming.
Thank you very much for inviting me. I’m, I’m really looking forward to talking about my project.

Your earlier books, you know, Planetfall and Cosmigraphics, really focused on sort of the beauty and the enormity of space, and this is a little bit the opposite. Like, you spent seven years in a tiny room in Canada ...
[Laughs.]
Looking at tiny things. Why did you decide to switch it up?
A lot of people don’t even remember the name Buckminster Fuller.
Mm-hmm.

He was a prominent futurist, very famous in the mid-20th century. And he was being interviewed, apparently, by a young journalist, a little bit nervous talking to the great man towards the end of his life, and the journalist said, “You’ve spent a career prognosticating about colonies in space and our position in space. Does it ever bother you that you haven’t actually been to space?” And Fuller looked at him and said. “My God, man, where do you think we are?”
[Laughs.]

And my point is that, actually, this is not that different from the other work I’ve been doing; it’s just that it’s at a different scale. It’s all about space and time, looking at how we try to understand our position and space and time using images, but I also write.

And with the electron microscope work it was finally having a chance to look at phenomena here on this planet. I wanted to look at natural design at submillimeter scales, so smaller than a grain of salt.
So huge, basically [Laughs].
So huge, basically—well, okay ...
I’m kidding [Laughs].

Well, no, it’s huge if you’re talking about, you know, atomic physics or something—we’re talking about large structures. That’s true [Laughs]. And we are talking about atomic physics because the electron microscope uses the electron and not the photon to look at subjects.
Yeah, I was gonna ask you about that. What makes a scanning electron microscope so different from [a] conventional lens-based microscope?

It’s quite different. It’s—first of all it takes up most of a room. It uses electrons instead of photons to look at the subjects, which allows for a far more detailed, nuanced, accurate look at extremely high magnifications of subjects.
From a very young age I was aware of electron micro—microscopy images, invariably presented as belonging to scientific research. But I’m an artist and a writer, and I’m not a, I’m not a scientist ...
Mm-hmm.
Although I am very science-adjacent. I use scientific technologies to explore phenomenal reality for my purposes.
Mm-hmm ...
You know, which is, you know, more associated with the arts; it is not science.

In what way is it art? Because I think when people think about taking an image of something or preparing a slide—what are the choices you’re making that make it different from, say, what people think of when they think of science?
So scientific imaging is about research and empirical data acquisition. I am positioning my work as belonging to the history of, of the image.
Mm-hmm.
The, the history of photography—although, in this case, it’s [micrography].
Mm-hmm.

But it looks like photography, and it’s printed like photography. And in fact, I approach it like photography, even—although it’s using a million-dollar piece of scientific research equipment that never leaves a single room—you know, a room ...
Yeah.
You can’t take it around [Laughs] and take photos with it. You have to bring the subjects to it.
There is a real learning curve learning how to use that kind of instrument ...
Mm-hmm.
And I have been fortunate in having the confidence of the Canadian Museum of Nature in Gatineau, Québec.
Mm-hmm.
I had a training period, and then they let me loose on the instrument.
It’s a very complex set of procedures just to get a sample ready for the SEM.
Mm-hmm.
SEM: scanning electron microscope.
Mm-hmm.
And that’s all exactly the same as what any scientist would do, exactly the same, you know?

Art has a freer hand than science. Art does not have to justify itself and prove things. Art is about sublimity—it can be—and about evoking wonder and about triggering aesthetic and emotional responses. And art is also, to quote something Brian Eno said recently—I don’t think he invented this, but it’s an interesting point—that art is, in some ways, how adults play.
Mm-hmm.
And furthermore, play is not wasting time—play, in children, is about figuring out their place in the universe in a way, to simplify.
Yeah.

And in my case this work is, in part, an extension of that impulse. You know, how to continue producing in myself this sense of wonder about our place in the universe, about the universe, you know, the phenomenal reality. And I’m also fascinated by frontiers.
One of the sets of images that open up the book are of these lunar moon rocks, and it’s interesting looking at them because they do—they look like mountainscapes to me.
Mm-hmm.
What are we looking at? [Gestures at a page in Nanocosmos.]

So it’s lunar impact glass, and it was a piece of ejecta, as they call it, you know, from a macrometeorite impact millions of years ago the Apollo 16 astronauts just kind of casually noticed lying on the lunar surface when they were doing something else and raked up—they had these rakes, sample rakes—and just threw in their sample bag and brought back to Earth.
Every single lunar image in the book—there aren’t that many ... [Flips to another page.]
Mm-hmm.
This is another lunar mountain range. They all came from the same piece of impact glass, which I just found marvelously ravaged and geological and, and, you know, landscapelike.
This is all fracturing ... [Points to an image in the book.]
Yeah.

From, from the impact, and—and I guess from the impact of the glass when it hit the surface. And then, and then, you know, there was—there were millions of years of exposure to space that resulted in various forms of weathering, let’s say.
[Flips to another page.] Here you have micrometeorite impacts.
Oh, yeah.
So they have—you can see, you know, characteristic lines radiating out, just like in macro lunar craters that we can see with a—through a telescope.
Yeah, that’s really cool.

Yeah. I very consciously wanted to make landscapes, lunar landscapes, on Earth. They look like Utah or Arizona slick rock country, you know? [Laughs.] They look very geological, and they are geological. It looks like something you could climb, you know? [Laughs.]
Yeah, it does.
Can I ask a very silly question?
Absolutely.
Did you lick it?
No.
[Laughs.]
Lick it—why?
I don’t know. There’s, like, a whole trend where—or a thing where people, like, feel compelled to, like, lick rocks, and you got [Laughs] ...

Oh, my God, these are Apollo samples. No chance would I, you know—and, and, and in fact, I wasn’t allowed to coat them. Because most samples you put in the electron microscope are coated with a molecule-thin layer of [a conductive material such as] platinum so that they don’t charge.
Mm-hmm.

And that’s complicated to explain. But you have an electron beam hitting the subject, you know, and if it’s not grounded with, with that coating, it can charge, and, and so on. And so I had issues with—I, of course, I couldn’t do that; these are priceless samples.
Mm-hmm.

And so I couldn’t do that, so I had to figure out ways of imaging, imaging them without them—their charging, and nobody who listens to this podcast is gonna sit through an explanation of how I did that ...
[Laughs.]
But, but I did manage to do that. But no, I did not lick them. [Laughs.]
[Laughs.] I mean ...
It’s a good question, though. [Laughs.]
Many of the images, like the image of the weevil in a flowering plant—I really like that one ...
Mm-hmm.
Become almost a world unto themselves ...
Yeah.
Because they’re taken so closely. They’re obviously so beautiful, but is there also, like, a scientific benefit to taking pictures like these?

Whether or not there’s a scientific benefit is beyond me, but as I said earlier I am fascinated by frontiers, wherever they may be. I define a frontier as where, where what we know or think we know meets what we know we don’t know ...
Mm-hmm.
You know? And, and, and there’s this sort of hazy zone in the sciences, where, where all of this research is taking place, and I am fascinated by that, but I’m not a scientist ...
Right.
I go there as an artist, looking for my kind of “discovery.”
You know, with those images of insects in plants, you know, I, I did have the benefit of being able to speak to and actually get loans from entomologists ...
Mm-hmm.

At the Museum of Nature. So I was asking things like, “Well, what does that thing do?” And then I would typically get an answer [such as], “Well, we believe it’s for this,” and I realize I’m at the frontier, you know?
Yeah.
“We believe it may be for this,” you know? So that’s, you know, that’s an interesting place.
[Gestures to a page in Nanocosmos.] So this is a flowering plant from the Adriatic, and when I collected it—the Croatian side of the Adriatic Sea ...
Mm-hmm.

And when I collected it—I mean, this is incredibly small. It’s about—the, the entire plant, let’s check [Flips to another page], the entire plant is eight millimeters wide, so that’s, you know, under a centimeter wide. And when I collected this thing with tweezers and put it in ethanol, I noticed that there was this weevil in it.
Mm-hmm.
And then they both, they both went in the ethanol. And so what you’re seeing is this kind of—I mean, very, very close to how it would look in actual nature, you know?
If someone actually paid attention to look.
Yeah.
Because—I mean, because it’s so small, it just feels like a thing that most of us would overlook.

Oh, yeah, of course. I mean, and also, who really looks at all those really tiny flowers? You just kind of trundle along, you know? [Laughs.] But I—one of the reasons why I really had a lot of fun with this project is it changed my way of looking at—my way of being in nature, you know?
Mm-hmm.
I mean, I was—of course, it was a little bit predatory [Laughs] when I was collecting samples.

[Flips through pages of Nanocosmos.] And there’s another one that’s similar to this that is even more ambitious in a way. In fact, I think it’s the single most complex mosaic I did in the whole book—all of these are mosaic images, by the way; they’re comprised of hundreds of individual scans. [Points to an image.] This is the one.
Oh.
Yeah, so that is—that’s from a—that’s an Ontario plant and a foxglove aphid in it.
Oh, yeah. [Points to a part of the image.] Right there.

Right there, yeah. And that one took about three weeks of continuous work to assemble because the, the individual SEM frame was something like this. [Turns the page to a closer view and indicates the size of the frame with his hands.]
Mm-hmm.

You know? And then there’s also a depth-of-field question. So, I mean, not to get all nuts and bolts on you here, but, you know, sometimes I had to do focus-stacking, get multiple scans of one part of the, of the subject in order to stack them in Photoshop and make sure everything was in focus, and then, you know, build a complex mosaic. So, yeah.
And this is—this has some elements of—you know that famous painting with the tiger in the jungle [Laughs] ...
Oh, yeah.
There’s a little bit of that going on.
Art isn’t prescriptive, but, like, what do you hope that people get from seeing these images?

I don’t know. I mean, you know, for example, those—the weevil surrounded by flowering plants was consciously modeled after 16th- and 17th-century Dutch still-life painting, where you’d see all the—you could see all these flowers and insects, all in a perfect arrangement, and just kind of, you know, life in miniature.
Mm-hmm.
It’s about triggering an aesthetic response. It’s about showing worlds that you can’t see with the naked eye, but we have these tools now to see them.
Mm-hmm.
See these worlds, you know? That, that also is all bound to this question of the frontier, of course.
Yeah.
Radiolarians, there’re these, like, you know, microscopic, basically, organisms ...
They are microscopic.
That live in the ocean.
Yep.
And—but they’re so beautiful. They’re almost, like, glassine in structure ...
They are.
But we would never be able to know about them without, you know, advancements in imaging, functionally.

Well, it’s interesting—radiolarians are specifically a, a, a central focus of the 19th-century German marine biologist Ernst Haeckel. He’s best known to the layperson as the author of a book that, in English, the title is Art Forms in Nature, which is really the first arts-science crossover illustrated book bestseller ever. And it’s still in print.
Yeah.
It’s incredible, you know? So he brought, let’s say, the message about radiolarians to the public in the late 19th century ...
Mm-hmm.
Discovered many of them. His work impacted design and architecture and art. He was using an optical microscope—the, the electron microscope had not been invented yet.
Mm-hmm.
He would’ve been envious, I think. [Laughs.]
[Laughs.]

I could look at radiolarians with a level of particularity that he could only dream of. But he did produce extraordinary work about radiolarians and many other organisms: diatoms, dinoflagellates … all kinds of things.

[Flips to a page in Nanocosmos.] So this is a radiolarian from the equatorial Pacific. It’s, it’s 300 microns wide, which means 0.3 millimeters; it’s extremely small. But look at the complexity there. And, you know, when it was fully intact and not partly damaged, it had a whole shell of this kind of latticework going on there [gestures to an image in the book]. And, you know, there—I write in the book about what all of these things are, we think, are doing, or at least to an extent: you know, what the—those radiating spines are all about. It’s partly about flotation in the water column. Yeah, so.
But the, the beauty of it is breathtaking to me. [Flips the page.] Here’s a closer ...
Closer.
View.
Yeah.
Yeah. I mean, it’s—there’s nothing like radiolarians anywhere else in nature that I’ve seen. I mean, in, in, in ...
Yeah.
Biological nature that I’ve seen. They’re, they’re quite specific.
And I think if we pop over here [Turns to another page] ...
Mm-hmm. Yeah, so these are, these are diatoms.
Mm-hmm.

And diatoms are another class of single-celled organism, and, and they tend to be much more sleek, as you can see here. And interestingly about diatoms, diatoms produce oxygen in the Earth’s atmosphere…
Yeah.
But they’re tiny, little things, you know? It’s just that there are billions of them. You have, you know, you have diatom blooms ...
Mm-hmm.
You see these long tendrils—you can see it from space, you know—of kind of greenish blooms in the water.

And all of the, the shells are actually glass—I mean, they’re silica, just like with radiolarians, by the way. The radiolarians are also—they distill silica from seawater and produce their, their shells from that. And under an optical microscope they look like glass.
Mm-hmm.
In an SEM you see the surface texture of the, of the glass, you know?

But the reason they do that—I mean, the reason that they have to be clear—is that they’re like petri dishes. [Laughs.] They have, they have symbiotic photosynthesis going on: algae living inside, producing energy.
Oh, that’s ...
For them, yeah.
[Looking at another page.] That’s, that’s a marine, marine diatom. Like a pillbox, isn’t it?
Mm-hmm.

Yeah. I mean, these—this just blows, blows me away. I mean, there, there’s an element of Islamic architecture, somehow, in here. [Turns the page.] This is a close view. I mean, this could be something in Istanbul, you know?
Yeah.
Flip it upside—flip it the other way, and it, and it could be the top of a building, you know, connected to a mosque or something.

[Flips back to the previous page.] Yeah, and so, you know, again, you know, what you have here, this is almost literally a petri dish. Look at it—it’s the same shape [laughs]. It’s a little bit more beautiful ...
[Points to part of the image on the page]—yeah, it’s almost, like, got lacing in there.
Yep, yep.
[Flips to another page.] And then we’re gonna bounce forward again.
Yep, so that’s a dinoflagellate, and, and we were talking about them earlier. I mean, they are so strange. They are so beautiful to me.

You have—usually, you have this sort of equatorial groove [Points to part of the image on the page] where one of the flagella coils around. And then you’ve got the—this, you know, polar opening here, where another flagella extends. They spin for stability, like a spacecraft might. [Laughs.] And then they’re propelled at the other end by this—another flagella, which shoots them forward. And they’re just amazing things, you know. And we don’t know what, what this is all about. What are these guys up to?
You know, there—I think that there’s a tendency to think that, “Well, we’re multicellular creatures, so a single cell must be a very simple thing.”
Mm-hmm.

You know, “’Cause we are complex, and we are made of many cells.” Well, it’s not so simple. I mean, the single-celled organisms that have managed to survive and compete with each other and prosper in the sea are—have just as much evolutionary history as we do. I mean, you know, four point something billion years, right?
Mm-hmm.
Or three point something, yeah. I really should know that, but we don’t, we don’t know that—nobody knows that for sure. In any case ...
It’s been a while. [Laughs.]
[Laughs.] It’s been a long time. It’s been a long, it’s been a long time.
So they—they’re very complex, and, you know, their survival strategies, their structural complexity is a result of the necessity to prosper, to go forth and prosper, you know?
Mm-hmm.

They had the same marching orders as Adam and Eve, I think, you know: “Go forth and prosper.” That’s, that’s life’s principle. [Laughs.] And, and so, you know, they’re, they’re very complex. They—and also, I guess nobody who actually knows anything about cells would say, “Well, a single cell is a, is a simple thing.” It’s—we—it’s a mysterious, complex, magical, amazing thing, anyway, even in a multicellular organism like us.
Mm-hmm.
But, but the ones that are free-floating and competing with each other are particularly amazing.
It feels like, in this moment, it’s really easy to be very cynical about everything, that there’s a lot of weight and heft going on in the world ...
Yeah, there is.
But hearing you talk about this book and this project, it seems like it reinforced your sense of wonder and ...
Yes.
Joy.
Yes, yes.

And I know that, you know, people have many emotions in looking at art, but it does feel like that if you—if people take away anything from your work, it should be kind of a sense of just how beautiful and weird and strange this world is.

Yes, thank you. That’s a great question. And you’re right. There’s also a spiritual element here. You know, I’m not a believer in any kind of organized religion, but, but I’m awestruck by where we are, you know, and, and, and, and, and so there is a, you know, there’s an element of, you know—I mean, okay, it sounds like a real cliche here—but communing or trying to understand, you know, “What is this? What is this project called life?” You know?
Mm-hmm.

And you’re right, you know, it—we are living in times where, with a lot of help from algorithms and social media and certain toxic politicians and so forth, we are focusing on negative things, largely, and our—on ourselves. The human race, like any life-form, probably, is focused on its own self, you know, largely. But my work has been to, in, in a sense, turn my back on—at least the visual work—on, on the, on the human race ...
Mm-hmm.
And look at nature, look at nonhuman phenomena.
Now, I don’t do that as a writer. I’m fascinated by the history of, of technology and science, and I have an opening essay in the book where I, where I trace the history of the microscope ...
Yeah.
So I’m, you know, I’m part of the human race, obviously. [Laughs.] I’m not an alien. But, but I do ...
Or at least that’s what you want us to believe. [Laughs.]

Well, maybe we’re all, maybe we’re all aliens; that’s another question. But in any, in any case it is about drawing the human gaze, ideally, away from our political squabbles, our social media, our—I don’t know, you know, all of these things that are pretty banal, actually, when you look at it, or I would say so. And look at—look out, look at where we are, look at the larger environment that actually produced us ...
Mm-hmm.
And look at creatures and organisms and phenomena that, that have developed alongside us for the same length of time as we have, you know?
Yeah. That feels like a good place to end this conversation. Thank you so much for your time. Thank you for joining us today.
Thank you very much for allowing me to expound on [Laughs], on my work. I appreciate it very much.
